content.description:
The right-hand SDS to the classic Rusty Blackbird, this problem adds two difficult moves before joining the direct line up the face.  
  
 SDS with an undercling for the left and a sloping, triangular edge for the right. Make two strenuous moves to get established on the triangular edges used for Rusty and continue to the top out. 
  
 While this line may or may not include a "true" V7 move, the right sit eliminates the "easier" start used in Rusty Blackbird and adds difficulty to the crux and top out of that line. Somewhat contrived,  but adds some more mileage to a great line and provides some excellent, hard climbing.

Starts slightly right of Rusty Blackbird on the Crow Boulder. The undercling is somewhat hidden but the triangular edge to the right should be obvious.
pad as per Rusty Blackbird, remember to protect the block found at the start of this problem during the crux and top out.

A possible warm-up for working the other lines found here, this problem starts on the left end of the Crow Boulder on a large jug. SDS and move left and up through more jugs and a diagonal crack in order to reach the top. Take care with the top out using the crack and moving slightly right to find feet.  
  
 This problem is also worth doing to check out the top out of Rusty Blackbird, which can be cruxy.

Left side (closest to the woods) of the Crow Boulder. The starting jug is just left of the starting holds for Rusty Blackbird.
pad

SDS with a large edge for the left hand and a hidden pocket/jug for the right. Make a big move right off the bat to stick the unique triangular, sloping edges in the centre of the wall. From here figure out a way to secure a higher good edge just below the lip and then move into the sloping, difficult top out. 
  
 This is an area classic with powerful moves through the face and a tenuous top out which requires a complete change of gears. Shorter individuals will have a harder time sticking the upper ledge as places for your feet disappear quickly, but keep at it and try a few of the less obvious footholds. Excellent climbing on good rock.

Smack in the centre of the Crow Boulder. One of the most-chalked problems here so picking it out shouldn't be too difficult.
pad or two, watch the block sitting just to the right of the problem as a fall from the crux or the top out tends to send climbers heading towards it.

SDS matched in a long vertical hueco and follow the line of sloping pockets and huecos directly up. For full value try to avoid using holds to either side of the interesting sloping features. This line is okay but awkward and short.

Found on the lake-facing side of the Crow Boulder, just to the right of Chrome Blackbird. The vertical line of sloping huecos is very obvious.
pad for the uneven landing

pathTokens: Halfway Log Dump (Bruce Peninsula National Park)

content.description: The final boulder found in the Shelf Beach and home to the moderate testpiece and area classic "Rusty Blackbird". The Crow sits close to the woods in an open area just above the other nearby boulders. Its slightly overhanging face greets climbers as they move up from the lower shelf and the tell-tale chalk marks should be obvious. Two warm-up lines are found on either end of the boulder, but the best problems by far head direct up the face.
